pli-tv-pvr1.2:1.1: Indulging in sexual intercourse how many offences does one fall into?
pli-tv-pvr1.2:1.2: Indulging in sexual intercourse one falls into three offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:1.3: if one indulges in sexual intercourse with a body that is not decayed there is an offence involving Defeat.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:1.4: If one indulges in sexual intercourse with a body that is practically decayed there is a grave offence.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:1.5: If without touching the male organ one makes it enter an open mouth there is an offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:1.6: Indulging in sexual intercourse one falls into these three offences. [1]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:2.1: Taking what has not been given how many offences does one fall into?
pli-tv-pvr1.2:2.2: Taking what has not been given one falls into three offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:2.3: if one takes as it were by theft something to the value of five _māsakas_ or more than five _māsakas_ there is an offence involving Defeat.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:2.4: If one takes … to the value of more than one _māsaka_ or less than five _māsakas_ there is a grave offence.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:2.5: If one takes … to the value of a _māsaka_ or less than a _māsaka_ there is an offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:2.6: Taking what has not been given one falls into these three offences. [2]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:3.1: Intentionally depriving a human being of life …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:3.3: if he digs a pitfall on purpose for a (certain) man, thinking, “Falling into it he will die,” there is an offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:3.4: If falling down into it a painful feeling arises (in the man), there is a grave offence.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:3.5: If he dies there is an offence involving Defeat.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:3.6: Intentionally … he falls into these three offences. [3]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:4.1: Laying claim (for oneself) to a non-existent, non-actual state of further-men …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:4.3: if, having evil desires, evil longings, he lays claim to a non-existent … there is an offence involving Defeat.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:4.4: If he says, “The monk who lives in this _vihāra_ is an arahant,” there is a grave offence for acknowledging (a conscious lie);
pli-tv-pvr1.2:4.5: there is an offence of wrong-doing for not acknowledging it.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:5.1: Concluded are the four Offences involving Defeat
pli-tv-pvr1.2:6.1: Emitting semen making an effort he falls into three offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:6.2: if he wills, makes an effort, and it is emitted there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:6.3: if he wills, makes an effort, and it is not emitted there is a grave offence;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:6.4: in (a certain) action there is an offence of wrong-doing. [1]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:7.1: Coming into physical contact with a woman one falls into three offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:7.2: if he rubs (her) body with (his) body there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:7.3: If he rubs an article of clothing (of hers) with (his) body there is a grave offence.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:7.4: If he rubs an article of clothing (of hers) with an article of clothing (of his) there is an offence of wrong-doing. [2]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:8.1: Offending a woman with lewd words he falls into three offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:8.2: pointing out the two privies, if he speaks in praise and speaks in dispraise there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:8.3: Leaving out (talk on) the two privies, pointing out any part from below the collar-bone to above the knee, if he speaks in praise and speaks in dispraise there is a grave offence.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:8.4: Pointing out an article of clothing, if he speaks … wrong-doing. [3]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:9.1: Speaking in praise of ministering to sense-pleasures for (him)self he falls into three offences;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:9.2: if he speaks … in the presence of a woman, there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:9.3: if he speaks … in the presence of a eunuch there is a grave offence;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:9.4: if he speaks … in the presence of an animal there is an offence of wrong-doing. [4]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:10.1: Acting as a go-between he falls into three offences;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:10.2: if he accepts, examines, brings back there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:10.3: if he accepts and examines but does not bring back, there is a grave offence;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:10.4: if he accepts, but does not examine, does not bring back, there is an offence of wrong-doing. [5]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:11.1: Begging for having a hut built for oneself he falls into three offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:11.2: if he has one built, in (each) operation there is an offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:11.3: If one lump (of plaster) is still to come there is a grave offence;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:11.4: when that lump has come there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order. [6]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:13.1: Defaming a monk with an unfounded charge of an offence involving Defeat he falls into three offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:13.2: if he speaks desiring his expulsion but without having gained his leave there is an offence of wrong-doing together with an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:13.3: if he speaks intending abuse, having gained his leave, there is an offence of insulting speech. [8]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:14.1: Defaming a monk with a charge of an offence involving Defeat, taking up some point as a pretext in a legal question really belonging to something else, he falls into three offences (_as in_ [8]). [9]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:15.1: A schismatic monk, though being admonished up to three times but not giving up (his course), falls into three offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:15.2: following the motion there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:15.3: following the two resolutions there are grave offences;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:15.4: following the conclusion of the (three) resolutions there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order. [10]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:16.1: Monks throwing in their lot with a schism, though being admonished up to three times but not giving up (their course), fall into three offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:17.1: A monk who is difficult to speak to, though being admonished up to three times but not giving up (his course) falls into three offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:18.1: A monk who brings a family into disrepute, though being admonished up to three times but not giving up (his course), falls into three offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:19.1: Concluded are the thirteen Offences requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order
pli-tv-pvr1.2:20.1: Exceeding the ten-day (period for wearing) an extra robe he falls into one offence:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:21.1: Being separated from the three robes for one night he falls into one offence:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:22.1: Exceeding (the period of) a month, having accepted robe-material not at the right time, he falls into one offence
pli-tv-pvr1.2:23.1: Having a soiled robe washed by a nun who is not a relation he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:23.2: if he has it washed there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:23.3: when he has had it washed there is an offence of Expiation involving forfeiture. [4]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:24.1: Accepting a robe from the hand of a nun who is not a relation he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:24.2: if he takes it there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:24.3: when he has taken it there is an offence of Expiation involving forfeiture. [5]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:25.1: Asking a man or woman householder who is not a relation for a robe he falls into two offences;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:25.2: if he asks there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:25.3: when he has asked … Expiation involving forfeiture. [6]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:26.1: Asking a man or woman householder who is not a relation for more robe-material than that (which they had invited him to accept) … (_see_ [6]). [7]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:27.1: Approaching a householder who is not a relation before being invited to do so and putting forward a consideration in regard to robe-material he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:27.2: if he puts forward a consideration there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:27.3: when he has put forward the consideration … Expiation involving forfeiture. [8]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:28.1: Approaching householders who are not relations … (_see_ [8]). [9]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:29.1: Succeeding in obtaining a robe by stating more than three times, by standing more than six times, he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:29.2: if he succeeds in obtaining it there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:29.3: when he has succeeded … Expiation involving forfeiture. [10]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:31.1: Having a rug made mixed with silk he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:31.2: as he has it made there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) operation;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:31.3: when he has had it made there is an offence of Expiation involving forfeiture. [11]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:32.1: Having a rug made of pure black sheep’s wool … (_see_ [11]). [12]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:33.1: Having a new rug made without taking a portion of white (wools) and a portion of reddish-brown colours, he falls into two offences … [13]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:34.1: Having a rug made every year … [14]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:35.1: Having a new rug to sit on made without taking a piece the breadth of the accepted span from all round an old rug … [15]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:36.1: Accepting sheep’s wool and exceeding the three _yojanas_ he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:36.2: if he makes the first foot go beyond the three _yojanas_ there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:36.3: if he makes the second foot go beyond there is an offence of Expiation involving forfeiture. [16]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:37.1: Having sheep’s wool washed by a nun who is not a relation … (_see_ [4]). [17]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:38.1: Accepting gold and silver he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:38.2: if he takes it there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:38.3: when he has taken it there is an offence of Expiation involving forfeiture. [18]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:39.1: Engaging in various transactions in which gold and silver are used … two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:39.2: if he engages there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:39.3: when he has engaged … Expiation involving forfeiture. [19]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:40.1: Engaging in various transactions in which there is bartering … (_see_ [19]). [20]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:41.1: The Second Division: that on Silk
pli-tv-pvr1.2:42.1: Exceeding the ten days (for keeping) an extra bowl he falls into one offence;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:43.1: Getting another new bowl in exchange for a bowl that has been mended in less than five places he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:43.2: if he gets in exchange there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:43.3: when he has got it in exchange there is an offence of Expiation involving forfeiture. [22]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:44.1: Having accepted medicines, (then) exceeding the seven days (for which they may be stored) he falls into one offence:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:45.1: Looking about for robe-material as a cloth for the rains while more than a month of the hot weather remains he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:45.2: if he looks about there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:45.3: when he has looked about there is an offence of Expiation involving forfeiture. [24]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:46.1: Having himself given robe-material to a monk, (then) angry and displeased, tearing it away he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:46.2: if he tears it away there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:46.3: when he has torn it away there is an offence of expiation involving forfeiture. [25]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:47.1: Himself asking for yarn, (then) having robe-material woven by weavers he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:47.2: if he has it woven there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:47.3: when it is woven there is an offence of Expiation involving forfeiture. [26]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:48.1: Before being invited by a householder who is not a relation, approaching weavers and putting forward a consideration in regard to robe-material he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:48.2: if he puts forward a consideration there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:48.3: when he has put forward the consideration there is an offence of Expiation involving forfeiture. [27]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:49.1: Having accepted a special robe, (then) exceeding the robe-season he falls into one offence:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:50.1: Having laid aside any one of his three robes in a house, (then) being separated from it for more than six nights he falls into one offence:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:51.1: Knowingly appropriating to himself an apportioned benefit belonging to the Order he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:51.2: if he appropriates it there is an offence of wrong-doing in (the) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:51.3: when he has appropriated it there is an offence of Expiation involving forfeiture. [30]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:52.1: The Third Division: that on a Bowl
pli-tv-pvr1.2:52.2: Concluded are the thirty offences of Expiation involving Forfeiture
pli-tv-pvr1.2:53.1: Telling a conscious lie how many offences does he fall into?
pli-tv-pvr1.2:53.2: Telling a conscious lie he falls into five offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:53.3: if, having evil desires, evil longings, he lays claim to a non-existent, non-actual state of further-men he falls into an offence involving Defeat;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:53.4: if he defames a monk with an unfounded charge of an offence involving Defeat there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:53.5: if he says, “The monk who lives in this _vihāra_ is an arahant,” he falls into a grave offence for acknowledging (the conscious lie),
pli-tv-pvr1.2:53.6: into an offence of wrong-doing for not acknowledging it;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:53.7: there is an offence of Expiation in conscious lying
pli-tv-pvr1.2:53.8: Telling a conscious lie he falls into these five offences. [1]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:54.1: Insulting he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:54.2: if he insults one who is ordained there is an offence of Expiation;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:54.3: if he insults one who is not ordained there is an offence of wrong-doing. [2]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:55.1: Bringing slander he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:55.2: if he brings slander against one who is ordained there is an offence of Expiation;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:55.3: if he brings slander against one who is not ordained there is an offence of wrong-doing. [3]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:56.1: Making one who is not ordained speak _Dhamma_ line by line he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:56.2: if he makes him speak there is an offence of wrong-doing in (the) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:56.3: an offence of Expiation for each line. [4]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:57.1: Lying down in a sleeping-place with one who is not ordained for more than two or three nights he falls into two offences;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:57.2: if he lies down in the action there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:57.3: when he has lain down there is an offence of Expiation. [5]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:58.1: Lying down in a sleeping-place with a woman … (_see_ [5]). [6]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:59.1: Teaching _Dhamma_ to a woman in more than five or six sentences he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:60.1: Speaking of a state of further-men that is a fact to one who is not ordained he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:60.2: if he speaks there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:60.3: when he has spoken there is an offence of Expiation. [8]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:61.1: Speaking of a monk’s very bad offence to one who is not ordained he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:62.1: Digging the ground he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:62.2: if he digs there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:62.3: in every thrust there is an offence of Expiation. [10]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:63.1: The First Division: that on Lying
pli-tv-pvr1.2:64.1: Destroying vegetable growth he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:64.2: if he destroys there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:64.3: in every assault there is an offence of Expiation. [11]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:65.1: Shelving the question by asking another he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:65.2: if evasion is not laid on him but he shelves the question by asking another there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:65.3: if evasion is laid on him and he shelves the question by asking another there is an offence of Expiation. [12]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:66.1: Making someone look down on a monk he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:66.2: while he is making someone look down on there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:66.3: when he has made someone look down on there is an offence of Expiation. [13]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:67.1: Having spread in the open air a couch or chair or a mattress or stool belonging to the Order, and not having removed it, setting out without asking permission (to do so) he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:67.2: if he makes the first foot go further than a stone’s throw there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:67.3: if he makes the second foot go further there is an offence of Expiation. [14]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:68.1: Having spread a sleeping-place in a _vihāra_ belonging to an Order, and not having removed it, setting out without asking for permission (to do so) he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:68.2: if he makes the first foot go further than the fence there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:68.3: if he makes the second foot go further there is an offence of Expiation. [15]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:69.1: Lying down in a sleeping-place belonging to an Order knowing that he is encroaching (on the space intended for) a monk who had arrived first he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:69.2: as he is lying down there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:69.3: when he has lain down there is an offence of Expiation. [16]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:70.1: Throwing out, being angry and displeased, a monk from a _vihāra_ belonging to an Order he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:70.2: as he is throwing out there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:70.3: when he has thrown out there is an offence of Expiation. [17]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:71.1: Sitting down on a couch or a chair that has removable feet and is in a lofty cell with an upper part in a _vihāra_ belonging to an Order he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:71.2: while he is sitting down there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:71.3: when he has sat down there is an offence of Expiation. [18]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:72.1: Having determined on two or three enclosures, (then) determining on (something) more than that he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:72.2: while he is determining there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:72.3: when he has determined there is an offence of Expiation. [19]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:73.1: Sprinkling water that he knows contains living things over grass or clay he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:73.2: while he is sprinkling there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:73.3: when he has sprinkled there is an offence of Expiation. [20]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:74.1: The Second Division: that on Vegetable-growth
pli-tv-pvr1.2:75.1: Exhorting nuns (though) he has not been agreed upon (to do so) he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:75.2: while he is exhorting there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:75.3: when he has exhorted there is an offence of Expiation. [21]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:76.1: Exhorting nuns after the sun has set … (_see_ [21]). [22]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:77.1: Exhorting nuns having approached nuns’ quarters … [23]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:78.1: Saying “Monks are exhorting nuns for the sake of gain” he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:78.2: while he is speaking there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:78.3: when he has spoken there is an offence of Expiation. [24]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:79.1: Giving robe-material to a nun who is not a relation he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:79.2: while he is giving there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:79.3: when he has given there is an offence of Expiation. [25]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:80.1: Sewing robe-material for a nun who is not a relation he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:80.2: while he is sewing there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:80.3: in each insertion of the awl there is an offence of Expiation. [26]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:81.1: Going along the same highway having arranged together with a nun he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:81.2: while he is going along there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:81.3: when he has gone along there is an offence of Expiation. [27]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:82.1: Embarking in one boat having arranged together with a nun he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:82.2: while he is embarking there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:82.3: when he has embarked there is an offence of Expiation. [28]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:83.1: Eating almsfood knowing it to be procured through (the intervention of) a nun he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:83.2: if he accepts it thinking, “I will eat” there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:83.3: for every mouthful there is an offence of Expiation. [29]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:84.1: Sitting down in a private place together with a nun, the one with the other, he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:84.2: while he is sitting down there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:84.3: when he has sat down there is an offence of Expiation. [30]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:85.1: The Third Division: that on Exhortation
pli-tv-pvr1.2:86.1: Eating more than one meal at a public rest-house he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:86.2: if he accepts it thinking, “I will eat” (_see_ [29]). [31]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:87.1: Eating a group-meal he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:87.2: if he accepts it thinking, “I will eat” … [32]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:88.1: Eating an out-of-turn meal he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:88.2: if he accepts it thinking, “I will eat” … [33]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:89.1: After accepting two or three bowlsful of cake, (then) accepting more than that he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:89.2: while he is taking it there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:89.3: when he has taken it there is an offence of Expiation. [34]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:90.1: Partaking of solid food or soft food that is not left over after he has eaten and is satisfied he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:90.2: if he accepts it thinking, “I will eat” … (_see_ [29]). [35]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:91.1: Inviting a monk who has eaten and is satisfied to take solid food or soft food that is not left over he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:91.2: if, at his bidding, he accepts saying, “I will eat, I will partake of” there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:91.3: at the end of the meal there is an offence of Expiation. [36]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:92.1: Partaking of solid food or soft food at the wrong time he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:93.1: Partaking of solid food or of soft food that has been stored he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:94.1: Eating sumptuous foods having asked for them for himself he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:95.1: Conveying to the mouth nutriment that has not been given he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:96.1: The Fourth Division: that on Food
pli-tv-pvr1.2:97.1: Giving with his own hand solid food or soft food to an unclothed ascetic or to a wanderer or to a female wanderer he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:97.2: while he is giving there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:97.3: when he has given there is an offence of Expiation. [41]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:98.1: Dismissing a monk after saying to him, “Come, your reverence, we will go into a village or market-town for almsfood,” whether he has caused (the almsfood) to be given or has not caused it to be given he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:98.3: while he is dismissing him there is an offence of wrong-doing in (each) action:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:98.4: when he has dismissed him there is an offence of Expiation. [42]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:99.1: Sitting down after intruding on a family with food he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:99.2: while he is sitting down there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:99.3: when he has sat down there is an offence of Expiation. [43]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:100.1: Sitting down in a private place on a secluded seat together with a woman he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:101.1: Sitting down in a private place together with a woman, the one with the other, he falls into two offences;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:102.1: Calling upon families before a meal or after a meal and, being invited and being (provided) with a meal, and not asking (for permission to enter) if a monk be there he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:102.2: when he makes the first foot pass the threshold there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:102.3: when he makes the second foot pass there is an offence of Expiation. [46]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:103.1: Asking for medicine for longer than that he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:103.2: while he is asking there is an offence of wrong-doing the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:103.3: when he has asked there is an offence of Expiation. [47]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:104.1: Going to see an army fighting he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:104.2: while he is going there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:104.3: standing where he sees there is an offence of Expiation. [48]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:105.1: Staying with an army for more than three nights he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:105.2: while he is staying there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:105.3: when he has stayed there is an offence of Expiation. [49]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:106.1: Going to a sham-fight he falls into two offences … (_as in_ [48]). [50]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:107.1: The Fifth Division: that on an Unclothed Ascetic
pli-tv-pvr1.2:108.1: Drinking strong drink he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:108.2: if he accepts it thinking, “I will drink,” there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:108.3: for every mouthful there is an offence of Expiation. [51]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:109.1: Making a monk laugh by tickling him with the fingers he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:109.2: while he makes him laugh there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:109.3: when he has made him laugh there is an offence of Expiation. [52]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:110.1: Sporting in the water he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:110.2: if he sports in the water with (the part) below the ankle there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:110.3: if he sports in the water with (the part) above the ankle there is an offence of Expiation. [53]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:111.1: Being disrespectful he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:111.2: while he is being disrespectful there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:111.3: when he has been disrespectful there is an offence of Expiation. [54]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:112.1: Frightening a monk he falls into two offences;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:112.2: while he is frightening him there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:112.3: when he has frightened him there is an offence of Expiation. [55]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:113.1: Warming oneself having kindled a fire he falls into two offences;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:113.2: while he is kindling it there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:113.3: when he has kindled it there is an offence of Expiation. [56]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:114.1: Bathing at intervals of less than half a month he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:114.2: while he is bathing there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:114.3: at the end of the bathe there is an offence of Expiation. [57]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:115.1: Making use of a new robe without taking any one of the three modes of disfigurement he falls into two offences;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:115.2: while he is making use of it there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:115.3: when he has made use of it there is an offence of Expiation. [58]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:116.1: Making use of a robe that has not been taken away and that he himself has assigned to a monk or a nun or a female probationer or a novice or a female novice he falls into two offences;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:116.2: while he is making use of it there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:116.3: when he has made use of it there is an offence of Expiation. [59]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:117.1: Hiding a monk’s bowl or robe or piece of cloth to sit on or needle-case or girdle he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:117.2: while he is hiding it there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:117.3: when he has hidden it there is an offence of Expiation. [60]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:118.1: The Sixth Division: that on Fermented Liquor and Spirits
pli-tv-pvr1.2:119.1: Intentionally depriving a living thing of life how many offences does he fall into?
pli-tv-pvr1.2:119.2: Intentionally depriving a living thing of life he falls into four offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:119.3: if he digs a pitfall not on purpose (for a certain man) and thinks,
pli-tv-pvr1.2:119.4: “Whoever falls into it will die” there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:119.5: if a man, falling into it, dies there is an offence involving Defeat;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:119.6: if a _yakkha_ or a _peta_ or an animal in human form, falling into it, dies there is a grave offence;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:119.7: if an animal, falling into it, dies there is an offence of Expiation
pli-tv-pvr1.2:119.8: Intentionally depriving a living thing of life he falls into these four offences. [61]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:120.1: Making use of water knowing that it contains life he falls into two offences;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:120.2: while he is making use of it there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:120.3: when he has made use of it there is an offence of Expiation. [62]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:121.1: Opening up for a further (formal) act a legal question knowing it has been settled according to the rule he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:121.2: while he is opening it up there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:121.3: when he has opened it up there is an offence of Expiation. [63]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:122.1: Concealing a monk’s offence knowing it to be a very bad one he falls into one offence of Expiation. [64]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:123.1: Ordaining a man knowing him to be less than twenty years of age he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:123.2: while he is ordaining him there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:123.3: when he has ordained him there is an offence of Expiation. [65]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:124.1: Going along the same highway having arranged together with a caravan knowing it to be set on theft he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:124.2: while he is going along there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:124.3: when he has gone along there is an offence of Expiation. [66]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:125.1: Going along the same highway having arranged together with a woman … (_see_ [66]). [67]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:126.1: Not giving up a pernicious view though being admonished up to three times he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:126.2: an offence of wrong-doing as a result of the motion;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:126.3: an offence of Expiation at the end of the proclamations. [68]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:127.1: Eating together with a monk knowing him to be one who talks thus, has not acted according to the rule, and has not given up that view he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:127.2: while he is eating there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:127.3: when he has eaten there is an offence of Expiation. [69]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:128.1: Encouraging a novice knowing him to be thus expelled he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:128.2: while he is encouraging him there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:128.3: when he has encouraged him there is an offence of Expiation. [70]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:129.1: The Seventh Division: on What Contains Living Things
pli-tv-pvr1.2:130.1: When one is being spoken to by monks regarding a rule,
pli-tv-pvr1.2:130.2: saying, “I will not train myself in this rule of training, your reverences, until I have inquired about it from another monk, experienced, expert in Discipline,” he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:130.3: while he is speaking there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:130.4: when he has spoken there is an offence of Expiation. [71]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:131.1: Disparaging Discipline he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:131.2: while he is disparaging there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:131.3: when he has disparaged there is an offence of Expiation. [72]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:132.1: Putting (a monk) in confusion he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:132.2: if he confuses when confusion has not been put on him there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:132.3: if he confuses when confusion has been put on him there is an offence of Expiation. [73]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:133.1: Giving a blow to a monk when one is angry and displeased he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:133.2: as he gives it there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:133.3: when he has given it there is an offence of Expiation. [74]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:134.1: Raising the palm of one’s hand against a monk when one is angry and displeased he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:134.2: as he raises it there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:134.3: when he has raised it there is an offence of Expiation. [75]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:135.1: Defaming a monk with an unfounded charge of an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:135.2: as he is defaming there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:135.3: when he has defamed there is an offence of Expiation. [76]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:136.1: Intentionally arousing remorse in a monk he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:136.2: while he is arousing it there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:136.3: when he has aroused it there is an offence of Expiation. [77]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:137.1: Standing overhearing monks when they are quarrelling, disputing, engaged in contention he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:137.2: if he goes thinking, “I will hear” there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:137.3: standing where he hears there is an offence of Expiation. [78]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:138.1: Engaging in criticism after giving consent for legitimate (formal) acts he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:138.2: as he criticizes there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:138.3: when he has criticized there is an offence of Expiation. [79]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:139.1: Rising up from his seat and departing when the Order is engaged in decisive talk without giving his consent he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:139.2: in leaving the assembly by (the space of) the reach of a hand there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:139.3: when he has left there is an offence of Expiation. [80]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:140.1: Engaging in criticism after having given away a robe by means of a complete Order he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:141.1: Apportioning to an individual a benefit belonging to the Order knowing that it has been apportioned he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:141.2: as he is apportioning it there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:141.3: when he has apportioned it there is an offence of Expiation. [82]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:142.1: The Eighth Division: that on Regarding a Rule
pli-tv-pvr1.2:143.1: Entering, without announcing beforehand, the king’s women’s quarters he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:143.2: as he makes the first foot cross the threshold there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:143.3: as he makes the second foot cross there is an offence of Expiation. [83]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:144.1: Picking up a treasure he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:144.2: as he picks it up there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:144.3: when he has picked it up there is an offence of Expiation. [84]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:145.1: Entering a village at the wrong time without asking (for permission) if a monk be there he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:145.2: as he makes the first foot cross the enclosure there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:145.3: as he makes the second foot cross it there is an offence of Expiation. [85]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:146.1: Having a needle-case made that consists of bone or consists of ivory or consists of horn he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:146.2: as he is having it made there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:146.3: when he has had it made there is an offence of Expiation. [86]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:147.1: Having a couch or a chair made exceeding the (proper) measure, he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:148.1: Having a couch or a chair made covered with cotton he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:149.1: Having a piece of cloth to sit upon made exceeding the (proper) measure he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:150.1: Having an itch-cloth made exceeding the (proper) measure he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:151.1: Having a cloth for the rains made exceeding the (proper) measure he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:152.1: Having a robe made the measure of a Well-farer’s robe, how many offences does he fall into?
pli-tv-pvr1.2:152.2: Having a robe made the measure of a Well-farer’s robe he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:152.3: as he is having it made there is an offence of wrong-doing in the action;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:152.4: when he has had it made there is an offence of Expiation.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:152.5: Having a robe made the measure of a Well-farer’s robe he falls into these two offences. [92]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:153.1: The Ninth Division: that on a King
pli-tv-pvr1.2:154.1: Eating solid food or soft food, having accepted it with his own hand from the hand of a nun who is not a relation (and) has entered among the houses, how many offences does he fall into?
pli-tv-pvr1.2:154.2: Eating … he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:154.3: as he accepts it thinking, “I will eat,” there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr1.2:154.4: for every mouthful there is an offence to be confessed.
pli-tv-pvr1.2:154.5: Eating … he falls into these two offences. [1]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:155.1: Eating without restraining a nun who is giving directions he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:156.1: Eating solid food or soft food among families agreed upon as learners, having accepted it with his own hand he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:157.1: Eating solid food or soft food in forest lodgings, not announced beforehand, having accepted it with his own hand within a monastery, how many offences does he fall into?
pli-tv-pvr1.2:157.2: Eating … he falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:157.3: as he accepts it thinking, “I will eat” …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:157.5: Eating … in forest lodgings he falls into these two offences. [4]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:158.1: Concluded are the four offences to be Confessed
pli-tv-pvr1.2:159.1: Dressing, out of disrespect, with the inner robe hanging down in front or behind, how many offences does he fall into?
pli-tv-pvr1.2:159.2: Dressing, out of disrespect … he falls into one offence:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:159.4: Dressing, out of disrespect … he falls into this one offence. [1]
pli-tv-pvr1.2:160.1: Out of disrespect putting on the upper robe hanging down in front or behind, he falls into one offence:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:161.1: Out of disrespect going (sitting down) amid the houses having uncovered the body, he falls into one offence
pli-tv-pvr1.2:163.1: Out of disrespect going (sitting down) amid the houses making play with hand or foot …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:165.1: Out of disrespect going (sitting down) amid the houses looking about …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:167.1: Out of disrespect going (sitting down) amid the houses with (the robes) lifted up …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:169.1: The First Division: that on All Round
pli-tv-pvr1.2:170.1: Out of disrespect going (sitting down) amid the houses with loud laughter …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:172.1: Out of disrespect going (sitting down) amid the houses making a loud noise, a great noise …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:174.1: Out of disrespect going (sitting down) amid the houses swaying the body …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:176.1: Out of disrespect going (sitting down) amid the houses swaying the arms …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:178.1: Out of disrespect going (sitting down) amid the houses swaying the head …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:180.1: The Second Division: that on Loud Laughter
pli-tv-pvr1.2:181.1: Out of disrespect going (sitting down) amid the houses with the arms akimbo …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:183.1: Out of disrespect going (sitting down) amid the houses muffled up …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:185.1: Out of disrespect going amid the houses crouching down on the heels …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:186.1: Out of disrespect sitting down amid the houses lolling …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:187.1: Out of disrespect accepting almsfood inattentively …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:188.1: Out of disrespect accepting almsfood while looking about here and there …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:189.1: Out of disrespect accepting much curry only …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:190.1: Out of disrespect accepting heaped-up almsfood …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:191.1: The Third Division: that on Arms Akimbo
pli-tv-pvr1.2:192.1: Out of disrespect eating almsfood inattentively …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:193.1: while looking about here and there …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:195.1: Out of disrespect eating much curry only …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:196.1: Out of disrespect eating almsfood having chosen from the top …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:197.1: Out of disrespect covering up the curry or the condiment with conjey …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:198.1: Out of disrespect eating curry or conjey having asked for it for oneself if one is not ill …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:199.1: Out of disrespect looking at the bowls of others captious-mindedly …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:200.1: Out of disrespect making up a large mouthful …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:201.1: Out of disrespect making up a long morsel (of food) …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:202.1: The Fourth Division: that on Almsfood
pli-tv-pvr1.2:203.1: Out of disrespect opening the mouth when the mouthful has not been brought close …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:204.1: Out of disrespect putting the whole hand into the mouth when one is eating …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:205.1: Out of disrespect talking with a mouthful in the mouth …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:206.1: Out of disrespect eating while tossing up balls of food …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:207.1: Out of disrespect eating while breaking up the mouthfuls …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:213.1: The Fifth Division: that on the Mouthful
pli-tv-pvr1.2:214.1: Out of disrespect eating while making a hissing sound …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:218.1: Out of disrespect accepting a drinking cup with one’s hands soiled (with food) …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:219.1: Out of disrespect throwing out amid the houses the rinsings of the bowl with lumps of boiled rice …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:220.1: Out of disrespect teaching _Dhamma_ to someone with a sunshade in his hand …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:221.1: with a staff in his hand …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:222.1: with a knife in his hand …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:223.1: with a weapon in his hand …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:224.1: The Sixth Division: that on Hissing
pli-tv-pvr1.2:225.1: Out of disrespect teaching _Dhamma_ to someone who is wearing shoes …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:230.1: has a turban on his head …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:232.1: who is sitting on a seat when one is sitting on the ground …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:233.1: who is sitting on a high seat when one is sitting on a low seat …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:234.1: who is sitting when one is standing …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:235.1: who is walking in front when one is walking behind …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:236.1: who is walking along a path when one is walking at the side of the path …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:237.1: Out of disrespect easing oneself when one is standing …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:238.1: Out of disrespect easing oneself or spitting on green corn …
pli-tv-pvr1.2:239.1: Out of disrespect easing oneself or spitting in water how many offences does he fall into?
pli-tv-pvr1.2:239.2: Out of disrespect easing himself … he falls into one offence:
pli-tv-pvr1.2:239.4: Out of disrespect easing himself … he falls into this one offence. [75]
